bug.short_desc: Add Google Search for Eclipse Wiki

long_desc.thetext:
MediaWiki Search has some known limitations, like not working for 3-letter words (bug #214723).
A Google search capability should therefore be added, like Bjorn has recently done for www.eclipse: http://eclipse-projects.blogspot.com/2007/12/google-search-across-eclipse-projects.html
The Google Search could be integrated with the Search Results page ("Not finding what you were searching? - Try Google on this site:"). Editing the template here might be sufficient: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php?title=MediaWiki:Nonefound&action=edit
Wikipedia also adds several external search engines: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=&fulltext=Search See also bug 214723 comment 2.

I'd like to rename this bug to 'discontinue using the Eclipse search engine altogether, in favour of Google search' as it appears the Eclipse search results are useless (and the search/indexer consumes a non-trivial amount of resources).
Can I move this to Community/website and do that?

With respect to the Wiki, I don't know enough about Google search to judge.
In my understanding, the Wiki search is a) a different beast than Eclipse Website Search, and b) always more up-to-date than Google since its index is updated on the fly
I also don't have enough experience to judge the usefulness of Google Search vs. Mediawiki search on the Wiki.
Also, taking http://en.wikipedia.org/ as example, they're still keeping MediaWiki search along with the other external search engines. Perhaps it's a good idea to let the user choose?

I must also say, though, that searching "SVN" on http://en.wikipedia.org with the MediaWiki search engine give MUCH better results than on the Eclipse Wiki. Apparently they have tweaked their MySQL installation to allow 3-letter-words (see bug 214723).
The wiki search (actually, ou DB indexes) was fixed some time ago to allow three-character, and I believe 2 character searches to work. Do we still need Google to save the world here?
Closing as worksforme. The Wiki search is now competent with decent indexes.
